prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Imaging the AGN/host galaxy's cool ISM, 97-GHz continuum emission and molecular outflows
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The target is a very powerful AGN hidden behind 0.5 mag of galactic extinction. We are proposing observations to reveal its internal structure and dynamics after PSF-subtracting the nuclear emission, and have two-band JVLA observations approved under grade-B.
With ALMA we propose to determine the distribution of continuum and molecular gas emission throughout the multiple components, revealing internal motion, tracing the relative motion of the bulk of the molecular gas. Alongside, we will detect the cool continuum, and any synchrotron emission in comparison with higher resolution observations. The integrated flux in the CO(1-0) line is known to be 1.45 Jy km/s (Yun et al. 2004), and we have compiled a thorough far-IR-submm SED using Herschel and SCUBA2, allowing an accurate extrapolation to 97.3GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In band 3 we assume the measured unresolved CO(1-0) signal from PDS456 in Yun et al. (2004; 1.45 Jy km/s). We propose to tune the receiver to centre on this line, and point to the location of the AGN.
The host galaxy/AGN has known near-IR structure on a 3.5-acsec scale, and it is likely that any fainter structure also lies within 5 arcsec (15kpc at z=0.18).
In a configuration for 0.3-arcsec resolution, and an extent of up to 3.5-arcsec, we would expect to image up to 100 independent beams on the potential extent of the object. Assuming uniform flux distributed between 10 beams on brighter regions, this would lead to a flux of about 0.8\,mJy per beam integrated across the line.
In order to obtain significant detections of CO from any fainter regions of the target, and to probe the rotation curve or resolved velocity dispersion in the host, we propose to achieve a sensitivity of 0.2 mJy per synthesized beam in each 50-km/s channel, corresponding to a total signal-to-noise ratio integrated across the whole line and target of about 220. Any emission from a broad CO(1-0) outflow component would be in addition to this estimate, being missed from the earlier OVRO image (Yun et al. 2004; Fig 1-centre). At the expected few per cent level, it should be readily detectable, and provide a ratio of line strengths in the high-velocity component.
The requested 0.3-arcsec resolution in order to reveal any rotation curve structure in the host, and resolve apart CO(1-0) emission from the near-IR detections K1-3 (Fig.1) and the AGN host.
All expected structure lies well within the ~52-arcsec primary beam at 97GHz.
We set up the basebands with one on CO(1-0) and the other three in the sidebands for continuum measurements.
The corresponding integrated continuum sensitivity in a 7.5-GHz bandwidth in dual polarization is 10microJy (1-sigma), which could detect PDS456 if it is as bright as the expected extrapolated dust flux density of 0.06 mJy at 97 GHz, derived from SCUBA2 observations at 350GHz. There could be up to an additional 1mJy of extrapolated non-thermal radio emission in addition, which would provide a valuable limit to the high-frequency synchrotron emission, expected to be co-located with the AGN. There will be a precise limit to the extended host emission.
We anticipate a 15 km/s resolution being perfectly reasonable to map the 181 km/s source. The settings for the correlator offer a choice fo 9 km/s or a very broad coverage, and so we choose 9 km/s.

The existing near-infrared and CO(1-0) imaging from OVRO unsurprisingly shows no structure larger than 3.5 arcsec, and the source will fit safely inside the primary beam.
We desire the best standard angular resolution to separate emission from the immediate environment of the AGN and the wider host galaxy, and any companions.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Imaging warm molecular gas from the AGN/host galaxy
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We propose to obtain observations of CO(3-2) at a matched spatial and spectral resolution to CO(1-0) in order to compare the line ratios and velocity profile of emission from the host galaxy, the precincts of the AGN and any high-velocity outflow. We expect CO(1-0) and CO(3-2) lines to be excited in all regions of the target.
We know the expected continuum flux density of the galaxy, and so we can also make a detailed dust distribution map, and be sure that there is no missing flux.
We augment this search with observations in Band-9 to probe even more excited material in both lines and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our observation in Band 7 is centred on CO(3-2), to provide the same sensitivity and velocity width as in Band 3, and thus to detect this line more significantly than CO(1-0) in the excitation cases discussed in the science goal above. An integrated line strength of about 10 Jy.km/s is reasonable, which with the assumptions above would correspond to a flux of 5.5mJy per beam across the full width of the line. A sensitivity of 0.4mJy per synthesized beam per 50-km/s channel should assure more than three times as significant a detection for CO(3-2) than for CO(1-0), with a reasonable expectation of a signal-to-noise ratio of 4 per 50-km/s channel in each synthesized beam, or 750 integrated over the whole line and source. A total signal to noise ratio of 750 should ensure than any broad outflow component, even at only the few percent level, is readily detected, providing a spatially-resolved excitation measure versus CO(1-0) in the outflowing gas.
The 292.06-GHz tuning corresponds to significantly finer angular resolution for the same baselines as the band-3 observation. We would like to detect the source at the same resolution for a good comparison, and so we specify 0.3-arcsec resolution in this science goal in order to allow matched observations.
The issues of spatial resolution are identical to those in Band 3. The other three basebands are set to sample the continuum.
The corresponding 280-290-GHz continuum sensitivity (1-sigma) is 28 microJy, which should give a very significant detection of the continuum structure in the target, which we estimate at 3.0 mJy, giving a 100-sigma continuum detection, integrated over the source. This will allow dust colour-temperature-emissivity maps to be produced throughout the source versus the Band-3 and Band-9 observations, and to be certain of any non-thermal excess in band 3.

The choice of 1 km/s in the baseband for the CO line is well suited to averaging. The coarsest available 30 km/s resolution is a little too broad for the expected 200 km/s width of the targetted line, and the expected velocity dispersion in the host galaxy.

See science goal above. The angular resolution is chosen to match the that set above for comparitive imaging. The maximum extent of the source remains 3.5 arcsec, inside the centre of the primary beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Line and continuum imaging of the AGN/host galaxy nearer to the SED peak
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We propose to observe at the frequencies of CO(7-6) and CI in the target to obtain the best possible spatial resolution, to better separate the emission from the hotter AGN and the cooler host galaxy, in the dust continuum, and to probe the higher-excitation gas likely to found in any active star-forming regions of the host, and near to the AGN. High-velocity molecular gas, flowing out from the vicinity of the AGN should also be detectable most easily in this transtion.
The relative sensitivity of observations for this target means that continuum detection is assured, and line detection should be possible. The excellent spatial resolution from the warm dust will provide a very powerful constraint on the relative strength of host and AGN emission.
This non-standard mode is necessary to probe the SED of the host galaxy in a higher-energy line as compared with the peak of the line SED. If there is highly-excited CO/hot dust near the AGN, then this would be highlighted in this highest-frequency band.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The highest-frequency observation includes basebands that are tuned to search for both CO(7-6) at 681.29GHz and [CI] at 683.57GHz. If CO(7-6) is excited as moderately as in Danielson et al. (2011), then we would expect an integrated line flux of 8.5 Jy.km/s; if as extreme as Riechers et al. (2011), then we would expect 46 Jy.km/s. We expect comparable fluxes in the [CI] line. See also Bothwell et al. (2013), Carilli \& Walter (2013) and Spilker et al. (2014) for line ratios.
We propose to reach a sensitivity of 5mJy in a 50km/s channel, to provide matched spectral resolution to the lower-excitation line searches in the most compact configuration C34-1 with 0.57-arcsec resolution, and a reasonable chance of detecting the line in the highly-excited case, and around the nucleus.
This spectral image can be used to compare in size to the other bands, to reveal internal structure in the continuum emission, including temperature information, as the SED peaks at an observed frequency of 1-3THz, and differences in the emission longwards will only appear in this band (Fig.2-right). We propose to ensure that there is no missed emission by centering this observation with a smaller primary beam midway between the AGN and K1-3 (Fig.1 left).
A 1-sigma sensitivity of 0.24mJy per beam is expected in the 680-GHz continuum, which should ensure a very significant detection of the expected 23mJy flux density (Fig.1 right), providing a spatially resolved image that will highlight the warmest dust. The total integrated signal-to-noise ratio on the continuum source is expected to be about 100.
The coarsest available choice of 14 km/s is well suited to the expected 200 km/s width of the line.

As above, the maximum source extent is expected to be well within the primary beam at 3.5 arcsec. The resolution is chosen to match with that in the above settings to ensure consistent and readily comparable images.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: PDS456 is an extremely-luminous, infrared-bright AGN at modest z=0.18, with an accurate SED from WISE, Herschel and SCUBA-2. Its SED and total luminosity closely match those of the spectacular, ultraluminous, dust-obscured, high-redshift AGNs detected by WISE ("HotDOGs"), but PDS456 is more accessible. From ongoing X-ray spectral monitoring, and optical/UV HST spectroscopy, we know that it has persistent, varying, very-broad absorption features, that indicate outflow speeds up to 0.35c. These features indicate a hugely-luminous AGN accreting close to its Eddington limit. PDS456 thus provides a unique opportunity to study the host and engine of an ultraluminous AGN. We propose to use ALMA's excellent spectral and spatial sensitivity to resolve its molecular gas, understand the galaxy around its remarkable AGN, to probe the source of its fuel, and the nature of energy and momentum feedback into the ISM/IGM. ALMA is the first telescope that can probe detailed position-velocity structure in both the host and molecular outflows. We will probe the ISM throughout the host galaxy of a prototype for the most luminous AGNs found at the peak epoch of galaxy formation/out to reionization.
